+Because the extension is in two parts, it can be harder to configure.
+The following scenarios lead to bad configurations:
+
+- Having a test method annotated with `@StdIo` that does not have `StdIn` or `StdOut` parameters
+- Having a test method with `StdIn` or `StdOut` parameters that is not annotated with `@StdIo`
+- Supplying values to the `@StdIo` annotation on a test method that does not have an `StdIn` parameter

+The `StdIn` and `StdOut` classes both contain the `capturedLines()` method that returns the lines read by `StdIn` or written to `StdOut`.
 This array contains the redirected in- or output as lines.

+

+

\ No newline at end of file
+class ExampleConsoleReaderTest {
+

+    @StdIo({ "line1", "line2", "line3" })
+    void testReadLines(StdIn in) {
+        ExampleConsoleReader consoleReader = new ExampleConsoleReader();
+

+
+        assertEquals(in.capturedLines(), "line1", "line2");
+    }
+
+}
+----

+This fails!

The note about no parameter is not needed. Two sentences before you already mentioned that.
Furthermore it interrupts  the "surrounding" two sentenced which belong together. I would rewrite the latter of them to something like "If you want to provide no input/expect no output, just use the annotation without additional values".
Third: The arrays does not only contain values which are provided to System. in but also expected values printed by System.out.

I don't get this. The if tests if the value array is not empty and if the parameter does not contain StdIn, but the error messages says that there are parameter but StdIn was * not* provided. Which is totally fine, if StdOut was provided and the values are the expected written values.
Did you miss to add the check for StdOut, because you want to check if there is a) an annotation with values but b) neither StdIn or StdOut parameter?
If the array is not empty, then you provided values for StdIn - which is incorrect if you don't have and StdIn parameter.

The method gets no values provided, so the expected result is that out.capturedLines() is empty.
Where do the expected lines come from? (I know - from the code itself, but you get what I mean?)
You don't provide values to System.out - you want to test that your SUT writes to System.out what you expect it to.
The expected lines come from the app.write() method. In it, there are calls to System.out.println() - which are redirected to StdOut by the extension.

Just a note:
This nested class should be thread safe due the use of @TestMethodOrder regarding to JUnit 5 User Guide

The default execution mode is applied to all nodes of the test tree with a few notable exceptions, namely test classes that use the Lifecycle.PER_CLASS mode or a MethodOrderer (except for Random).
Is this Namespace intended to be created from DefaultLocaleExtension.class?
Oops. 😅

Could this break if only one of StdIn or StdOut is used?
System.in or System.out may end up being null if one of these .get(...) calls returns null.
Yeah, should probably check if it even needs to be reset first.
I added more tests to cover this case and changed the behaviour.

The @StdIo annotation must be present. The StdIoExtension itself is not public and can only be registered with the annotation.
We could delete this condition and exception because this never happens and could be confusing.
I switched annotation detection to our utils (so meta-annotations are found as well), which forces us to consider the absent case because it returns an Optional.

This exception is never thrown. Could be deleted.
From the ParameterResolver::resolveParameter documentation:

This method is only called by the framework if supportsParameter(org.junit.jupiter.api.extension.ParameterContext, org.junit.jupiter.api.extension.ExtensionContext) previously returned true for the same ParameterContext and ExtensionContext.
Without this line, the compiler complains because the method does not return/throw on all paths. I prefer an exception over return null.
